data.title: Nuri As-Said - A Study in Arab Leadership by Lord Birdwood: Very Good Hardcover (1959) First Edition.
data.meta_description: First Edition. - Hardcover - Cassell (1959), London - 1959 - Condition: Very Good - No Dust Jacket - No signatures. Lacking the dust-jacket. ; xi, [2 (double-page map)], 306 pages + frontispiece + 15 illustrations on 4 plate leaves. 4 other maps within the pagination. Black cloth boards with gilt lettering on spine. Page dimensions: 216 x 137mm. Biography. Chapters include: The Desert Campaign, 1916-17; The Encirclement of Deraa, 1918; Damascus and the End of the War; The Peace Conference, 1919, and Anglo-French Conflict; War and Peace as viewed from Baghdad; The Era of Treaties; Rashid Ali and the Three Weeks' War; Egypt and the War of Words; Iraq and Jordan answer the United Arab Republic; Epilogue: Revolution and Assassination; Glossary of Arabic Words. "The tragic death of the young King Feisal of Iraq and of his Prime Minister, Nuri as-Said, in the revolution of July, 1958, made the name of Iraq's leading statesman a household word overnight. Already known as a firm friend to Britain and as one of the architects of the Baghdad Pact, he was responsible for Iraq's uncompromising resistance to the wiles of Egyptian propaganda. Little, however, is generally known of his early life, and Lord Birdwood, in his biography of this truly great man, has traced his rise to power against the background of the whole Middle East question." - from dust-jacket blurb (this copy lacking the dust-jacket). - Nuri As-Said - A Study in Arab Leadership
data.text:
About this Item

No signatures. Lacking the dust-jacket. ; xi, [2 (double-page map)], 306 pages + frontispiece + 15 illustrations on 4 plate leaves. 4 other maps within the pagination. Black cloth boards with gilt lettering on spine. Page dimensions: 216 x 137mm. Biography. Chapters include: The Desert Campaign, 1916-17; The Encirclement of Deraa, 1918; Damascus and the End of the War; The Peace Conference, 1919, and Anglo-French Conflict; War and Peace as viewed from Baghdad; The Era of Treaties; Rashid Ali and the Three Weeks' War; Egypt and the War of Words; Iraq and Jordan answer the United Arab Republic; Epilogue: Revolution and Assassination; Glossary of Arabic Words. "The tragic death of the young King Feisal of Iraq and of his Prime Minister, Nuri as-Said, in the revolution of July, 1958, made the name of Iraq's leading statesman a household word overnight. Already known as a firm friend to Britain and as one of the architects of the Baghdad Pact, he was responsible for Iraq's uncompromising resistance to the wiles of Egyptian propaganda. Little, however, is generally known of his early life, and Lord Birdwood, in his biography of this truly great man, has traced his rise to power against the background of the whole Middle East question." - from dust-jacket blurb (this copy lacking the dust-jacket).
